revision.text:
{{italic title}} {{Infobox artwork | image_file = Jean-Antoine Watteau - The Country Dance - Google Art Project.jpg | painting_alignment = | image_size = | title = The Country Dance | alt = | other_language_1 = French | other_title_1 = La Danse Champetre | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = [[Jean-Antoine Watteau]] | year = 1706-1710 | type = [[Oil painting]] on [[canvas]] | height_metric = | width_metric = | length_metric = | height_imperial = 19.5 | width_imperial = | length_imperial = 23.625 | diameter__metric = | diameter_imperial = | imperial_unit = in | metric_unit = cm | city = [[Indianapolis]] | museum = [[Indianapolis Museum of Art]] | coordinates = | owner = }}
'''''The Country Dance''''' is an [[oil painting]] by [[France|French]] artist [[Jean-Antoine Watteau]], located in the [[Indianapolis Museum of Art]], which is in [[Indianapolis]], [[Indiana]]. Probably Watteau's earliest painting, created roughly 1706-1710, it depicts a group of quite courtly peasants dancing among the trees.<ref name=lee/>
==Description== Amid the trees, a group of villagers play music while a couple dances. A toddler copies the lady's motions, entertaining the company. Rather than the usual contemporary association with debauchery, music here alludes to social harmony and order. The musicians glance coyly at the viewer, actors very aware of their spectators. This sort of interaction is one of Watteau's hallmarks.<ref name="lee">{{cite book|last1=Lee|first1=Ellen Wardwell|last2=Robinson|first2=Anne|title=Indianapolis Museum of Art: Highlights of the Collection|publisher=[[Indianapolis Museum of Art]]|location=[[Indianapolis]]|date=2005|isbn=0936260777}}</ref>
It is an image of visual extremes: the dark forest background brings the peasants' bright clothing into sharp contrast. The rustic setting and the dancers' formal attire channel both the [[fête galante]] and a formal court celebration transplanted to a charming bit of countryside.<ref name=porter>{{cite book|last=Porter|first=Cecelia Hopkins|title=Five Lives in Music: Women Performers, Composers, and Impresarios from the Baroque to the Present|year=2012|publisher=[[University of Illinois]]|location=[[Urbana, Illinois]]|isbn=9780252037016|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2Dc-8Z8-zLQC&pg=PA41&dq=country+dance+Watteau&hl=en&sa=X&ei=y-AKUfP4I4btygGj0YCYBg&ved=0CDoQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=country%20dance%20Watteau&f=false}}</ref>
==Historical information== This is Watteau's earliest known painting, but already he had developed his own style. Painted shortly after he moved from [[Valenciennes]] to [[Paris]], Watteau took the merry rustic scenes favored by his [[Flemish people|Flemish]] antecedents like [[Pieter Bruegel the Elder|Pieter Bruegel]] and [[Peter Paul Rubens]], but gave them unprecedented grace, nobility, and style. Though painting a standard northern European subject, he drew heavily on Venetian landscapes, particularly in the atmospheric effects. It is, in effect, a declaration in favor of the [[Rococo]] movement with which Watteau would become so heavily associated.<ref name=ima>{{cite web|title=The Country Dance|url=http://www.imamuseum.org/art/collections/artwork/country-dance-jean-antoine-watteau|publisher=[[Indianapolis Museum of Art]]|accessdate=31 January 2013}}</ref>
===Acquisition=== ''The Country Dance'' was acquired by the IMA in 1974, a gift of Mrs. Herman C. Krannert. It hangs in the Charles O. McGaughey Gallery and has the accession number 74.98.<ref name=ima/>
==See also== * ''[[The Embarkation for Cythera]]''
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links==
*[http://www.imamuseum.org/art/collections/artwork/country-dance-jean-antoine-watteau IMA page]
{{Jean-Antoine Watteau}} {{IMAart}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Country Dance, The}} [[Category:1700s paintings]] [[Category:Indianapolis Museum of Art artworks]] [[Category:Paintings by Antoine Watteau]] [[Category:Musical instruments in art]] [[Category:Dance in art]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2017}} {{Infobox award | name = UK Music Video Awards | current_awards = 2018 UK Music Video Awards | description = excellence in music video and moving image for music | country = United Kingdom | year = 2008 | website = [http://www.ukmva.com/ www.ukmva.com] }} The '''UK Music Video Awards''' is an annual celebration of [[creativity]], technical excellence and [[innovation]] in [[music video]] and moving image for music. The awards began in 2008. There is a wide range of opportunities for [[United Kingdom|UK]] individuals and companies to enter their work: from genre-led video categories, to prizes for individuals in the technical and craft areas of the business, to recognition for innovative approaches to music videos, [[Advertising|ads]] and other visuals.{{Cite news |url=http://www.musicweek.com/media/read/bowie-beyonce-and-radiohead-among-uk-music-video-awards-nominees/066022 |title=UK Music Video Awards returns; entries now open |date=June 28, 2016 |work=Music Week}} There are also awards for international videos and outstanding individuals, voted for by the MVA jury members.{{Cite news |url=http://www.nme.com/news/music/foals-99-1247060 |title=Foals, Florence + The Machine, James Blake nominated for UK Music Video Awards |date=October 13, 2013 |work=NME}} The Awards take place in the autumn, with the entry process opening in early August. The UK MVA’s are organised by two of the key members of the team behind BUG, the [[BFI Southbank]]’s music video strand, and have 20 years’ experience running events in the UK music video business. ==2008== The 2008 UK Music Video Awards, hosted by [[Adam Buxton]], took place at the Odeon West End, Leicester Square, London on October 14th.{{cite web|url=https://www.promonews.tv/news/2008/10/14/uk-music-video-awards-2008-all-winners/1466 |title=UK Music Video Awards 2008 - all the winners! |publisher=Promonews |date=14 Oct 2008}}{{cite web|url=https://www.ukmva.com/Pages/Detail/84-2008 |title=UKMVA Past Winners 2008 |website=www.ukmva.com |access-date=14 Nov 2018}} {| class="wikitable" |- !Video of the Year !Best Pop Video !Best Rock Video |- |'''[[Björk]] — "[[Wanderlust (Björk song)|Wanderlust]]"'''

An '''umbrella title''' is a formal or informal name connecting a number of individual items with a common theme.<ref>[http://www.library.yale.edu/~okerson/yea/yeaappendC.pdf Description of Metadata Elements in the Yale Electric Library Archive (glossary)]</ref> It is most often used in lieu of listing separately the separate components or providing a convenient "label" for a collection of [[discipline]]s.
==Uses of umbrella titles== ===Academia=== Nonspecific fields of study are identified by umbrella titles such as "[[physics]]", "[[physical education]]", and "[[medicine]]", to distinguish them from specialized fields of study such as [[exercise physiology]].<ref>[http://faculty.css.edu/tboone2/asep/julyasep.html Glossary from American Society of Exercise Physiologists newsletter, July 1999]</ref>
===Scientific conferences and discussions=== Many [[scientific conference|scientific]] and [[academic conference]]s use umbrella titles as unifying themes for the activities scheduled in the course of the conference.<ref>[http://www.aafp.org/online/en/home/cme/cmea/glossary.html Glossary from American Academy of Family Physicians]</ref>
===Employment=== Umbrella titles in common use involve either general job descriptions of a group of workers with similar responsibilities (like "teacher")<ref>[http://66.218.69.11/search/cache?ei=UTF-8&p=%22Umbrella+title%22+definition&fr=slv8-msgr&u=www.dps109.org/File.asp%3FID%3D1027%26ws%3D&w=%22umbrella+title%22+definition&d=SsirS_mdOeij&icp=1&.intl=us Collective Bargaining Agreement between Board of Education Deerfield District #109 and Deerfield Education Association, IEA-NEA]</ref> or rank (military or nonmilitary).
===Politics and law=== Collections of organizations with a common legal or legislative interest are often "united" under an umbrella title for the purposes of [[lobbying]] or participating in a [[lawsuit]].<ref>[http://www.sierraclub.org/environmentallaw/blog/2006/09/global-warming-in-supreme-court.asp "Global Warming in the Supreme Court"] - Sierra Club article mentioning umbrella groups (and an umbrella title) in lawsuit</ref>
===Entertainment and literature=== Umbrella titles are widely used in music, literature, television, and theater. Uses of umbrella titles vary widely in the arts, to a much greater spectrum of use than in other fields of study.
====Music and dance==== Umbrella titles are used to demarcate the music field into general trends or styles: [[classical music]], [[jazz]],<ref>[http://www.umass.edu/fac/media/danilo.pdf University of Massachusetts program for Danelo Pérez concert] - includes history and terminology of jazz</ref> [[rock music]], [[hip hop]], [[rhythm and blues]] and other labels which each cover more specialized musical styles. A similar "structure" can be found in the field of dance.
Prior to the sale of the [[long playing record]] in 1950, albums containing several 78 revolutions-per-minute records were often sold under umbrella titles (a collection of recordings from ''[[Oklahoma (musical)|Oklahoma]]'', for example). It can be argued that titles of all long-playing records and [[compact disc]]s are "umbrella" titles—and several such recordings with a common theme often have an umbrella title (such as [[Chip Davis]]' "[[Mannheim Steamroller|Day Parts]]" series) as well.
====Television==== While it can be argued that every title of a televised series, especially those primarily used to designate a time period rather than actual programming (like ''NBC Monday Night at the Movies'') is an umbrella, the term is more appropriately applied to names of [[anthology series]], series that combine together to provide a common theme (such as the three components of ''[[90 Bristol Court]]''), [[wheel series]], and other series under a common heading (such as ''[[Crimetime After Primetime]]'' and ''[[Four in One]]'').
While it was common practice in the 1950s and early 1960s for series to alternate or otherwise share a time slot in [[United States|American]] broadcast network television (for example, ''[[The Jack Benny Show]]'' shared a time slot with, first ''[[Private Secretary (TV series)|Private Secretary]]'' and then ''[[The George Gobel Show]]''), umbrella titles were not used by United States' networks until 1964, when [[NBC]] presented three half-hour programs on Monday nights as a programming block centered at a southern California apartment complex, ''90 Bristol Court''.<ref>Tim Brooks and Earle Marsh, ''The Complete Directory to Prime Time Network and Cable TV Shows, 1946-Present'' (2003) {{ISBN|0-345-45542-8}}</ref><ref>''TV Guide Guide to TV 2006'' (2006) {{ISBN|0-7607-7572-9}}</ref>
While the 1964 programming experiment did not succeed (two of the series were cancelled; the third lasted the broadcast season but was not renewed for the 1965-1966 season), NBC was not dissuaded from further programming experimentation. Within a decade, the network then experimented with wheel series, first with ''Four in One'' and ''[[The Bold Ones]]'', then with ''[[NBC Mystery Movie]]''. Afterwards additional wheel series were presented by American broadcast networks, to varying degrees of success. The expirement was revived in 1979 with ''[[Cliffhangers (TV series)|Cliffhangers]]''.
In the United Kingdom, umbrella titles were used in varying degrees in their programming as well. The long-running ''[[Doctor Who]]'' used umbrella titles on several levels, first with individual named episodes under the umbrella of the title of an overall story (the first four episodes were commonly called "An Unearthly Child" even though none of them actually showed it to be the title of the story); even after the naming of individual episodes ceased, umbrella titles were often used to collect [[story arc|stories with a common enemy or theme]] ([[Dalek]]s stories, [[Cyberman|Cybermen]] stories, [[United Nations Intelligence Taskforce|UNIT]] stories, and season-long "Key to Time" and "[[The Trial of a Time Lord|Trial of a Time Lord]]").
====Motion pictures and literature==== The use of umbrella titles in motion pictures parallels their use in literature. Movie trilogies such as ''[[The Lord of the Rings (film series)|Lord of the Rings]]'' and the ''[[Three Colors]]'' trilogy (''a.k.a.'' "Red, White, and Blue trilogy") commonly are called by umbrella titles, as was the case for their literary cousins (such as [[John Dos Passos]]' ''[[USA trilogy|U.S.A.]]''). Umbrella titles were often used to cover longer sequences of motion pictures or novels (such as the [[James Bond]] and ''[[Star Wars]]'' films and [[Marcel Proust]]'s multi-volume ''[[Remembrance of Things Past]]''). Often umbrella titles are used to collect motion pictures with common stars ("[[Marx Brothers]] movies") or common characters ("[[Dirty Harry]] movies"), as is the case for novels or comics ("[[Perry Mason]] novels", for example). In literature, sometimes an umbrella title is used for a collection of stories with a common locality, such as the [[Wessex]] novels of [[Thomas Hardy]].
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Television terminology]] [[Category:Literature]]
[[de:Umbrella title]]

{{about||the German slalom canoeist|Walter Horn (canoeist)|the German entomologist|Walther Hermann Richard Horn}} '''Walter W. Horn''' (18 January 1908 – 26 December 1995) was a [[medieval studies|medievalist scholar]] noted for his work on the [[Timber framing|timber]] [[vernacular architecture|vernacular]] [[medieval architecture|architecture of the Middle Ages]]. He was born in [[Germany]], but fled [[Nazism]] and spent most of his [[academia|academic career]] at the [[University of California, Berkeley]], where he became the university system's first [[art historian]] and co-founded the History of Art department. A [[naturalized citizen]] of the [[United States]], Horn served in the [[U.S. Army]] during [[World War II]] and then in the [[Monuments, Fine Arts, and Archives program|special intelligence unit]] that tracked down [[Nazi plunder|art works plundered by the Nazis]]. His most celebrated exploit was the recovery of the [[crown jewels]] of the [[Holy Roman Empire]], also known as [[Charlemagne]]'s [[Imperial Regalia]].<ref>W. Eugene Kleinbauer, James Marrow and Ruth Mellinkoff, "Memoirs of [[Fellow#Academia|Fellows]] and Corresponding Fellows of the [[Medieval Academy of America]]: Walter W. Horn," ''Speculum'' 71 (1996), p. 800 ("his most important piece of detective work led to the recovery of the coronation regalia of the Holy Roman Empire"); "Walter Horn," ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'', 30 December 1995, [http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/1995/12/30/MN38089.DTL&type=printable obituary]; University of California (System) Academic Senate, "1996, University of California: In Memoriam," [http://content.cdlib.org/view?docId=hb0z09n6nn&chunk.id=div00030&brand=calisphere&doc.view=entire_text "Walter Horn, History of Art: Berkeley"] ("his most spectacular feat was the recovery of Charlemagne's ceremonial regalia").</ref> As a scholar, Horn is most noted for his work on the medieval [[architectural drawing]] known as the [[Plan of Saint Gall]].
==Early life== Horn was born in the town of [[Waldangelloch]] in rural [[Grand Duchy of Baden|Baden]]. His mother was Matilde Peters; she married Karl Horn, a [[Lutheran]] minister. Walter [[Education in Germany|attended a ''Gymnasium'']] in nearby [[Heidelberg]] and went on to study [[art history]] at the [[University of Heidelberg]] and the [[University of Berlin]]. He earned his [[doctorate]] in 1934 at the [[University of Hamburg]], studying under [[Erwin Panofsky]]. His [[dissertation]], ''Die Fassade von Saint-Gilles'', on the [[façade]] of [[Saint-Gilles, Gard]], was published in 1937.
==World War II era== [[File:Weltliche Schatzkammer Wien (169)pano2.jpg|thumb|150px|As a [[Monuments, Fine Arts, and Archives program|special intelligence officer]], Horn recovered the "crown of Charlemagne", part of the [[Imperial Regalia]] hidden by the Nazis]] Horn fled Germany in opposition to the Nazi regime. He continued his studies from 1934 to 1937 as a research associate at the German Institute for the History of Art in [[Florence, Italy]]. In 1938, Horn moved to the [[United States]] and began his long association with the University of California, Berkeley, as a [[lecturer]]. A year later, he was given a permanent position as the first art historian in the University of California system.<ref>[http://content.cdlib.org/view?docId=hb0z09n6nn&chunk.id=div00030&brand=calisphere&doc.view=entire_text UC In Memoriam], p. 87.</ref> During this time, he married Ann Binkley Rand.
Horn became a [[naturalized citizen]] in 1943. That same year, he volunteered for [[military duty]] in the [[U.S. Army]]. By 1945, he was a [[lieutenant]] in the [[Third United States Army|Third Army]] under General [[George S. Patton]]. Horn's skills as a native speaker of [[German language|German]] were put to use in [[interrogation|interrogating]] [[prisoners of war]]. After the war, he continued as a special investigator in the [[Monuments, Fine Arts, and Archives program]], using his expertise as an art historian to track down [[Nazi plunder|art that had been stolen or concealed by the Nazis]]. Horn served until 1946, attaining the rank of [[Captain (United States)|captain]].
In 1946, Horn succeeded in recovering the [[Imperial Regalia]] of [[Charlemagne]], the [[Imperial Crown of the Holy Roman Empire|crown]], [[sceptre]], and [[Imperial Regalia#Components|jewels]] of the [[Holy Roman Empire]]. These had been kept hidden by Germans who hoped to return to power even after their defeat by the [[Allies of World War II|Allies]]. <ref>[http://content.cdlib.org/view?docId=hb0z09n6nn&chunk.id=div00030&brand=calisphere&doc.view=entire_text UC In Memoriam.]</ref> The incident has been elaborated, sometimes with inaccuracies, by writers who take particular interest in the [[Holy Lance]], the spear supposed to have pierced the side of [[Jesus]] during [[Crucifixion of Jesus|his crucifixion]]. This artifact is sometimes called the Spear of Destiny and identified with the [[Holy Lance#Vienna Lance (Hofburg spear)|Vienna Lance]], one of the components of the regalia. In speculative works of [[non-fiction]] that endow the lance with [[National Socialism and Occultism|occult powers or mystical significance in Nazism]],<ref>See Trevor Ravenscroft, ''The Spear of Destiny: The Occult Power behind the Spear Which Pierced the Side of Christ'' (Red Wheel, 1982). Ravenscroft reproduces a portion of Horn's report on the recovery of the regalia (called there "insignia"), [https://books.google.com/books?id=BKt_4HbED6AC&pg=PA348&lpg=PA348&dq=spear+%22Walter+W.+Horn%22&source=bl&ots=F3xrA_ZVM1&sig=Pku4BJhvr_4T9V8nLeZdLbCtIXw&hl=en&ei=pWtvSpmaOIbiNe7kqdoI&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1 p. 348.] For issues raised by Ravenscroft's methodology, see [[Holy Lance#Trevor Ravenscroft|Holy Lance: Trevor Ravenscroft]].</ref> Horn appears in narratives about its retrieval from the possession of [[Adolf Hitler]].<ref>A detailed version by Jerry E. Smith and George Piccard, ''Secrets of the Holy Lance: The Spear of Destiny in History and Legend'' (Adventures Unlimited Press, 2005), pp. 267–270 [https://books.google.com/books?id=qGX3ZtD_UikC&pg=PA267&dq=%22The+Hunt+for+the+Spear+In+1945%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=3 online]; see also E. Randall Floyd, ''100 of the World's Greatest Mysteries'' (Harbor House, 2000), [https://books.google.com/books?id=uM1Fx9og0B4C&pg=PA262&dq=%22Finally,+on+April+30,+1945,+U.S.+troops%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=3 pp. 262–263]; Lionel Fanthorpe and Patricia Fanthorpe, ''Mysteries and Secrets of the Templars: The Story behind the Da Vinci Code'' (Dundurn Press Ltd., 2005), [https://books.google.com/books?id=rcErzxJsJlIC&pg=PA57&dq=%22It+was+also+part+of+the+lance%27s+legend%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=3 p. 57.]</ref> Usually identified as "Lt. Walter William Horn," he is said to have retrieved the lance at the behest of Patton on the very day of Hitler's death, that is, 30 April 1945.
==The McCarthy era== Returning from the war, Horn married Alberta West Parker, a [[physician]], who became a Clinical Professor of Public Health at UC Berkeley.<ref>San Francisco Chronicle, March 31, 2012, [http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/sfgate/obituary.aspx?n=alberta-horn&pid=156776720#fbLoggedOut Alberta Horn, obituary]</ref> In 1949, Horn and his family became embroiled in the controversy at his university over a [[loyalty oath]] requirement. During the era of the [[Cold War]], the [[Red Scare]], and [[McCarthyism]], the [[Board of Regents]] at the University of California began to require that all university employees sign an oath affirming their loyalty to the [[California constitution|state constitution]] and denying their membership or belief in organizations advocating the overthrow of the [[U.S. government]]. The requirement met with resistance, and in the summer of 1950 thirty-one [[Professors in the United States|professors]]<ref>Along with a number of other employees.</ref> who refused to sign were fired, despite their stature as "internationally distinguished scholars."<ref>[http://sunsite.berkeley.edu/uchistory/archives_exhibits/loyaltyoath/symposium/index.html The University Loyalty Oath.]</ref> Horn's fellow [[medieval studies|medievalist]] [[Ernst Kantorowicz]] resigned rather than sign the oath, stating his reasons in two letters to the [[university president]] that were only published in English decades after the episode. Kantorowicz also presented a letter from Horn, who had signed the oath under protest. In the letter dated 23 August 1950, Horn, then acting [[chairman]] of the art department, pointed to his former military service and to his voluntary [[reactivation]] that same month as a [[reservist]] in the [[United States armed forces|Armed Services]].
{{quote|Being thus confronted a second time with a disruption of my academic career, and feeling unable to expose my wife and my son to the consequences of being denied continuance of my civilian occupation upon return from military duty, it is with profound regret that I find myself compelled to yield to the pressure which the Regents saw fit to exercise in order to extort from me a declaration concerning my political beliefs. I am enclosing the requested statement, signed. I should like to make known that, in doing so, I am acting against the better precepts of my [[conscience]] and for no other reason than that of protecting my family against the contingencies of economic distress. … It was in avoidance of pressures of this type that I left Germany in 1938 and came to this country. And it was in the desire of contributing to the eradication of such methods that I volunteered during the last war to take up arms against the country of my birth. I am expecting my recall to active duty [[Korean War#Escalation|in the present conflict]] with the bitter feeling that, this time, I shall be fighting abroad for the defense and propagation of [[Freedoms]] which I have been denied in my professional life at home.}}
Kantorowicz noted that Horn's letter "illustrates the grave conflict of conscience and savage [[economic coercion]] to which, after fifteen months of pressure and struggle, he had finally to yield."<ref>Horn's letter appears following two letters by Kantorowicz at The University Loyalty Oath: A 50th Anniversary Retrospective, [http://sunsite.berkeley.edu/uchistory/archives_exhibits/loyaltyoath/symposium/kantorowicz.html "The Fundamental Issue."]</ref>
==Academic career and scholarship== [[File:Firenze.Baptistry06.JPG|thumb|200px|Horn established methods for dating with his work on the [[Florence Baptistry]]]] [[File:Great Coxwell Tithe Barn c.jpg|thumb|200px|[[Great Coxwell Barn]] was one of two Cistercian structures studied by Horn and [[Ernest Born]] for their first book]] Horn's early position as research associate in Florence gave him firsthand knowledge of the city's [[Cathedral architecture of Western Europe|medieval church architecture]] and produced two important studies, ''Das Florentiner Baptisterium'' (1938), an analysis of the fabric and ornamentation of the [[Florence Baptistry]] that established new criteria for its dating, and ''[[Romanesque architecture|Romanesque]] Churches in Florence: A Study of Their [[Chronology]] and Stylistic Development'' (1943), which included an examination of the [[masonry]] construction of [[San Miniato al Monte]]. Throughout his career, he continued to explore the conceptual connections between [[Classical architecture|classical]] and northern architecture.<ref name="content.cdlib.org">[http://content.cdlib.org/view?docId=hb0z09n6nn&chunk.id=div00030&brand=calisphere&doc.view=entire_text "Walter Horn, History of Art: Berkeley"]</ref> His specialty was [[Aisle#Cathedral architecture|three-aisled]] timber structures in medieval churches, [[Market house|market halls]] and [[manor house|manor halls]]. He was known for arriving at a precise dating of medieval buildings through studying [[Architectural engineering|their technologies]] and observing the physical evidence, drawing on scientific disciplines; he dated timber structures with reference to [[radiocarbon dating|radiocarbon analysis]] and [[Dendrochronology|dendrochronological tables]].<ref>Kleinhauer ''et al.'', "Memoir," p. 801. See, for example, Walter Horn, "The Potential and Limitations of Radiocarbon Dating in the Middle Ages," in ''Scientific Methods in Medieval Archaeology'', edited by [[Rainer Berger]] (Berkeley and Los Angeles, 1970), pp. 23-87.</ref>
In 1958, Horn published what is considered his most important article,<ref>Kleinhauer ''et al.'', "Memoir," p. 800.</ref> "On the Origins of the Medieval Bay System" in the ''Journal of the [[Society of Architectural Historians]]''. He argued that [[Bay (architecture)|bay]]-divided [[Cathedral architecture of Western Europe|medieval churches]] derived from [[Germanic peoples|Germanic]] timber buildings and represented a continuous tradition of [[vernacular architecture]] in [[transalpine]] Europe. Horn was the first to assemble the known timber examples, which dated from as early as 1200 BC and extended into the medieval period. Because traces of early wooden structures were often scanty or oblique, Horn used scientific methods to uncover their architectural principles, and demonstrated that these were developed and applied to stone [[cathedral]]s in the Romanesque and [[Gothic architecture|Gothic]] periods.<ref>Kleinhauer ''et al.'', "Memoir," p. 800; [http://content.cdlib.org/view?docId=hb0z09n6nn&chunk.id=div00030&brand=calisphere&doc.view=entire_text "Walter Horn, History of Art: Berkeley"]; [http://www.dictionaryofarthistorians.org/hornw.htm Dictionary of Art Historians.]</ref>
The 1958 article was significant also in that it marked Horn's first collaboration with [[Ernest Born]], the [[San Francisco|San Franciscan]] architect and [[draftsman]] with whom he was to author a series of books and articles over the next twenty years. Their first book was ''The Barns of the [[Beaulieu Abbey|Abbey of Beaulieu]] at Its [[wikt:grange|Granges]] of [[Great Coxwell Barn|Great Coxwell]] and Beaulieu St. Leonard'' (1965), a study of the only two [[Cistercian]] [[tithe barn]]s, dating from the 13th century, that survive in England.<ref name="content.cdlib.org" /> But their major project was the three-volume work ''The Plan of St. Gall: A Study of the Architecture and Economy of, and Life in a Paradigmatic [[Carolingian Renaissance|Carolingian]] Monastery'', which has been called "one of the greatest [[monograph]]s on medieval architecture that has ever appeared."<ref name="Kleinhauer p. 801">Kleinhauer ''et al.'', "Memoir," p. 801.</ref>
===Plan of St. Gall=== [[File:Pianta dell'abbazia di san gallo, 816-830, san gallo, stiftbibliothek.jpg|left|thumb|250px|The [[Plan of Saint Gall]]]] The [[plan of Saint Gall]] had engaged Horn's imagination and curiosity since he was introduced to it by his mentor [[Erwin Panofsky]].<ref>Kleinhauer ''et al.'', "Memoir," p. 800.</ref> In 1957, Horn had participated in an international [[academic conference|congress]] on the plan, and his interest in its guest and service buildings led to his survey of medieval structures in France and England. In 1965, Horn and Born contributed to the creation of a [[scale model]] of the 40 buildings rendered on the plan. The model was displayed at the international exhibit ''[[Charlemagne|Karl der Grosse]]'' held at [[Aachen]]. Their two decades of collaboration culminated in a work of 1,056 pages with an estimated 1,200 illustrations.
''The Plan of St. Gall'' was praised by French historian [[Emmanuel LeRoy Ladurie]] for its "prodigious scholarship," and for its wide-ranging elucidation of [[Carolingian Renaissance|Carolingian]] daily life.<ref name="obituary">William Grimes, "Walter Horn, 87, a Historian Of Medieval Cloisters and Barns," ''[[New York Times]]'' 29 December 1995, [https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/29/nyregion/walter-horn-87-a-historian-of-medieval-cloisters-and-barns.html?pagewanted=print obituary]</ref> The first volume offers a reconstruction of the church and the living quarters for a [[Christian monasticism|community of monks]] numbering about a hundred. The second volume covered the guest and service buildings and the [[Medieval gardening|horticultural]] spaces for growing vegetables, medicinal herbs, and fruit and nut trees. The third volume contains supplemental material such as Horn's 88-page catalogue of the plan's explanatory ''tituli'', or captions, and [[Charles W. Jones (medievalist)|Charles W. Jones]]' English translation of the ''Consuetudines Corbienses'' by [[Adalard of Corbie|Adalhard]] of the [[abbey of Corbie]].<ref>See [[Charles W. Jones (medievalist)|Charles W. Jones]] for more on this collaboration.</ref> Through meticulous reimagining of the activities that the architecture was meant to facilitate, Horn presents a rich picture of Carolingian life and thought.
The most controversial aspect of the work was Horn's major thesis: that the plan was a copy of a lost [[blueprint|master plan]] dating to 816 or 817 that would have been part of documents pertaining to the official monastic reform movement under [[Louis the Pious]] at Aachen. The dominant strand of criticism to the contrary holds that the plan was intended to represent an ideal and was never meant to be carried out at a particular site. Horn's last article on the plan, "The Medieval Monastery as a Setting for the Production of Manuscripts,"<ref>Co-authored with Born in the ''Journal of the Walters Art Gallery'' 44 (1986) 16–47.</ref> was a response to this criticism.<ref name="Kleinhauer p. 801" />
''The Plan of St. Gall'' earned twelve major awards for its scholarship, [[bookbinding|bookmaking]], and [[typography]], including a prize from France's [[Académie d'architecture]] and a 1982 medal from the [[American Institute of Architects]].<ref>Kleinhauer ''et al.'', "Memoir," p. 801; Grimes, ''NYT'' obituary.</ref>
===Later work=== In 1974, Horn retired to [[emeritus]] status after 36 years at the University of California. His last publication, ''The Forgotten [[Hermitage (religious retreat)|Hermitage]] of [[Skellig Michael]]'' (1990), co-authored with Jenny White Marshall and Grellan D. Rourke, resulted from [[fieldwork]] begun in 1978 on [[List of islands of Ireland|Ireland's Atlantic offshore islands]]. His interest in the Celtic [[Roundhouse (dwelling)|roundhouse]] had been indicated earlier in "On the Origins of the Medieval Cloister" (1973).
===Honors and administrative achievements=== Horn worked with [[classical archaeologist]] [[Darrell A. Amyx]] to establish History of Art as a separate department at the University of California in 1971. He was a [[Fellow#Academia|fellow]] of the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] (elected 1970) and of the [[Medieval Academy of America]] (1980). Horn was an active supporter of arts institutions outside academia, serving as [[trustee]] of the [[Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco]] and chairman of the museum's acquisitions committee.<ref>''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'', 30 December 1995, [http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/1995/12/30/MN38089.DTL&type=printable obituary "Walter Horn."]</ref> He was on the board of the [[College Art Association]] 1950–54 and 1964–68 and on the board of the [[Society of Architectural Historians]] 1964–68.
==Death== Horn died at home of [[pneumonia]] on Tuesday, 26 December 1995, at [[Point Richmond, Richmond, California|Point Richmond]], California. He was 87. He was survived by his wife, Alberta; his son, Michael; two daughters, Rebecca and Robin; and a grandson, Matthew. His [[obituary]] in the ''[[New York Times]]'' labeled him "historian of medieval [[cloister]]s and [[barn]]s."<ref name="obituary"/> Horn was remembered by colleagues as one of the university's "best-loved and most influential teachers and … most effective leaders."<ref>"Walter Horn, History of Art: Berkeley," [http://content.cdlib.org/xtf/view?docId=hb0z09n6nn&doc.view=frames&chunk.id=div00030&toc.depth=1&toc.id= Calisphere.]</ref> He was eulogized for "his oratorical skills and uncanny ability to bring the medieval building or pile of [[ruins]] vividly to life. His eloquence and grace matched his endless curiosity about prehistoric and medieval buildings in northern Europe and how people utilized them."<ref>Kleinhauer ''et al.'', "Memoir," pp. 801–802.</ref>
==Selected bibliography== Standard biographical and publishing data on Horn not otherwise cited comes from two or more of the following sources. * W. Eugene Kleinbauer, James Marrow and Ruth Mellinkoff. "Memoirs of Fellows and Corresponding Fellows of the [[Medieval Academy of America]]: Walter W. Horn," ''Speculum'' 71 (1996) 800-802. * University of California (System) Academic Senate, "1996, University of California: In Memoriam," [http://content.cdlib.org/view?docId=hb0z09n6nn&chunk.id=div00030&brand=calisphere&doc.view=entire_text "Walter Horn, History of Art: Berkeley"] * ''Dictionary of Art Historians: A Biographical Dictionary of Historic Scholars, Museum Professionals and Academic Historians of Art'', [http://www.dictionaryofarthistorians.org/hornw.htm "Horn, Walter W(illiam)."] * William Grimes, "Walter Horn, 87, a Historian Of Medieval Cloisters and Barns," ''[[New York Times]]'' 29 December 1995, [https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/29/nyregion/walter-horn-87-a-historian-of-medieval-cloisters-and-barns.html?pagewanted=print obituary] * "Walter Horn," ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'', 30 December 1995, [http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/1995/12/30/MN38089.DTL&type=printable obituary] * "Walter Horn; Specialist in Medieval Architecture," ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', 31 December 1995, [http://articles.latimes.com/1995-12-31/news/mn-19602_1_medieval-architecture obituary] * Rihoko Ueno, [http://sirismm.si.edu/EADpdfs/AAA.hornwalt.pdf ''A Finding Aid to the Walter Horn Papers, 1908-1992, bulk 1943-1950, in the Archives of American Art''], Washington, DC 2012. * Brown, Hillary, [http://archives2.getty.edu:8082/xtf/view?docId=ead/920087/920087.xml;chunk.id=ref15;brand=default Finding Aid for the Walter Horn Papers], 1917-1989, at the Getty Research Institute, Los Angeles, 1997.

{{Infobox writer | name = Werner Sutermeister | image = Werner Sutermeister.jpg | imagesize = | caption = Werner Sutermeister, around 1896 | pseudonym = | religion = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1868|||df=y}} | birth_place = [[Zofingen]], [[Canton of Argovia|Argovia]], [[Switzerland]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1939|04|19|1868|||df=y}} | death_place = [[Switzerland]] | occupation = poet, novelist | language = [[German language|German]] | nationality = Swiss | ethnicity = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | yearsactive = | genre = | subject = | movement = | notableworks = ''Der Schüttelbecher''
''Der fröhliche Apfelbaum'' | spouse = | partner = | children = | relatives = | influences = | influenced = | awards = | signature = | website = | portaldisp = }} '''Werner Sutermeister''' (1868–1939) is a [[Swiss]] [[writer]] well known for his [[spoonerism]]s. == Life == Werner Sutermeister was a son of Ernestine Moehrlen and [[Otto Sutermeister]].''Der fröhliche Apfelbaum, geschüttelt von Werner Sutermeister.'' Bern: Hans Huber, 1932. {{ISBN|3-7185-0383-2}} attended [[Gymnasium Kirchenfeld]] in [[Berne]]. He then studied [[history]], [[German philology]] and [[philosophy]] in [[University of Basel|Basel]], [[University of Leipzig|Leipzig]] and [[University of Berne|Berne]]. In 1891 he became a teacher for [[secondary school]]s. 1894 he promoted with a dissertation about [[Klemens von Metternich]]’s relationship to [[Switzerland]] between 1840 and 1848.[http://bernensia.ch/biographien/sutermeister1868.php Biographie on bernensia.ch][https://books.google.ch/books?id=N9TjAAAAMAAJ&q=%22Werner+Sutermeister%22&dq=%22Werner+Sutermeister%22&hl=fr&sa=X&ei=SznkUPD7LoWA4gSv4ICwBg&ved=0CDcQ6AEwATgU Recension] in: ''[[Deutsche Literaturzeitung|Deutschen Literaturzeitung für Kritik der Internationalen Wissenschaft]]'', vol. 17, nr. 41–52, [[Weidmannsche Buchhandlung]], 1896 For six years he worked as a teacher at the girls' school of Berne. In the spring of 1900 he was elected to the [[Gymnasium of Berne]], where he taught History and German for 37 years. He also directed the orchestra of the Gymnasium.[[Paul Dübi]]: ''Über den Autor''. In: ''Der fröhliche Apfelbaum, geschüttelt von Werner Sutermeister.'' 2. erweiterte Auflage. [[Gute Schriften]], Bern 1973, Seite 77. {{ISBN|3-7185-0383-2}} Sutermeister also wrote for the Bernese daily newspaper ''[[Der Bund]]'': ::''He was a master of light-headed philosophy, and he shook the kaleidoscope of the German language to delight himself and the mischievous coincidences of his rhymes. So he has brought some cheerful, but also some thoughtful note in our newspaper text.''''Dr. Phil. Werner Sutermeister, alt Gymnasiallehrer in Bern, ist im Alter von 71 Jahren gestorben.'' In: ''[[Der Bund]]'', 20 April 1939, nr. 182, “Abend-Ausgabe”, page 4, with photo. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [[Manfred Hanke]]: [http://www.e-periodica.ch/digbib/view?pid=smh-002:1976-1977:56#1088 “Wer guet cha schüttle, cha wool rime.”] In: ''[[Schweizer Monatshefte|Schweizer Monatshefte. Zeitschrift für Politik, Wirtschaft, Kultur]].'' vol. 56, 1976/1977, p. 1023. {{Wikisource|de:Werner Sutermeister|Werner Sutermeister}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sutermeister, Werner}} [[Category:1868 births]] [[Category:1939 deaths]] [[Category:People from Zofingen]] [[Category:Swiss writers in German]] [[Category:Swiss male writers]] [[Category:Grotesque]] [[Category:19th-century Swiss poets]] [[Category:20th-century Swiss poets]] [[Category:20th-century male writers]] [[Category:Swiss poets in German]] [[Category:Swiss male poets]] {{Switzerland-writer-stub}}

| remarks = | formerly = | footnotes =<ref>{{cite web |url=https://writingnsw.org.au/wp-content/uploads/2018/05/2017-NSW-Writers-Centre-annual-report-and-Financial-Statements-.pdf|title=Annual Report 2017 |publisher=NSW Writers' Centre |date=April 2017 |access-date=1 November 2018 }}</ref> }} '''Writing NSW''', formerly known as '''New South Wales Writers' Centre''' and '''WritersNSW''', is [[New South Wales]], Australia's leading provider of services to writers, including courses, seminars and workshops, writing groups, festivals and events, grants and prizes, and information and advice. A not-for-profit organisation formerly known as the NSW Writers’ Centre, we have been providing quality support to the writers of our state since 1991.
Writing NSW is managed by Executive Director Jane McCredie. The director and staff are responsible to a management committee elected by Centre members. As of 2018 there were approximately 2,000 members.
The Centre offers a program of activities including workshops, seminars, festivals, grants and competitions, as well as mentorships, leveraging opportunities for emerging writers and suggesting pathways to publication. It is the peak body for writers in the state of New South Wales.
Writing NSW occupies Garry Owen House, a restored Georgian mansion set in the grounds of [[Callan Park Hospital for the Insane|Callan Park]]. The office is open from Monday to Friday 9:00 am to 5:00 pm and Saturday 9:00 am to 1:00 pm.
The change of name from the New South Wales Writers' Centre took place in 2018.
== External links == *[https://writingnsw.org.au/about] Writing NSW website

revision.text:
Founded in 1980, '''Zaccho Dance Theatre''' is a San Francisco based dance company. The company presents [[site-specific theatre|site-specific]] works as well as works inspired by environmental, cultural, and structural settings. Zaccho’s co-founder and artistic director, Joanna Haigood, is the company’s primary choreographer. The company has performed at prestigious festivals and art centers including the [[National Black Arts Festival]], [[Fall for Dance Festival]], [[Festival d'Avignon]] in France, [[Jacob's Pillow Dance]] Festival, the [[Walker Arts Center]], and the McColl Center for Visual Art. The company also runs a free arts education program for students age 7 to 17 at its studio in [[Bayview-Hunters Point, San Francisco]].
== References == *[http://www.zaccho.org/main.html Zaccho Dance Theatre Official Website] *[https://www.nytimes.com/2002/08/18/arts/dance-way-up-high-soaring-floating-diving-dancing.html New York Times review of Zaccho Dance Theatre performing "Picture Red Hook" in 2002] *[https://www.nytimes.com/2007/08/23/arts/dance/23pill.html New York Times review of Zaccho Dance Theatre performing "Invisible Wings" in 2007]
== External links == *[http://danceinteractive.jacobspillow.org/dance/zaccho-dance-theatres-invisible-wings Archival footage of Zaccho Dance Theatre performing Joanna Haigood's site-specific work "Invisible Wings" at Jacobs Pillow in 1998] *[http://fora.tv/2007/08/25/Eric_Foner_The_Underground_Railroad Archival footage of historian Eric Foner discussing the Underground Railroad in relation to Joanna Haigood's site-specific "Invisible Wings" and Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in August 25, 2007]
